utterances: Wow.
…you know, having worked for so long, I kind of know everyone.
I have a reputation in town.
I keep working and - so I can get those meetings, but it, you know, it took a long time to build a career.
You don't - it's very rare that you just come in with something and they put you in charge of a show.
Well, in your case it's also - isn't this a family business?
Well, to a certain extent.
We certainly weren't encouraged to enter the business, but my brother - one of my brothers created ""Will & Grace"" with a partner…
And your dad's a writer.
And my dad was the king of variety and specials for many, many years and keep - still keeps his hand in.
Thanks very much for the call, Ally.
Yeah, I appreciate it.
Good luck to you.
Thanks a lot.
All right.
You wrote for ""Gilmore Girls"" just before this, and we're not the only ones to notice that the - those two universes seemed to be at polar opposites.
Well, truthfully, you know, I worked on ""Gilmore Girls"" in the beginning of the show.
But that was Amy's baby, Amy Sherman-Palladino.

You know, we were - her room was there to help but, especially first season, that was her brainchild and, you know, I like to think I helped break stories and stuff, but I can't take much credit for ""Gilmore Girls"" or say that I had a great influence on the show.
It was another job that I enjoyed and then moved on.
The show is half an hour.
I guess there have been other shows on primetime cable outlets that - there are half an hour - ""Sex and the City,"" you think of, but why was the decision made to make it a half-hour show?
Showtime was in the market for a ""comedy,"" quote, unquote.
And the perception is that comedy is a half-hour.
And while I think we're a mix of comedy and drama - come-drama as one of our producers calls it - they wanted a half-hour show.
At first, I'd asked for an hour and they said no. In the end, I'm actually glad it's a half-hour.
I think there's a certain economy that we're forced to stick with.
And the storytelling is minimal and brisk and it's kind of exciting to get as much as we can into those 30 minutes.
It's a dense program.
Yes.
It's very, very dense.
And this is a program - it's hard to imagine it airing in any version on - even on basic cable.
Yeah.
There was some discussion of doing alternate versions for things, but I think it would be too overwhelming for us to replace everything that might be construed as inappropriate for mainstream.
Although you have networks like Comedy Central and FX that are taking more and more risks.
On the other hand, they still have advertisers to answer to and that the slippery slope.
Congratulations.
Thanks very much for being with us.
My pleasure.
Thank you for having me.
Jenji Kohan, creator and executive producer of ""Weeds."" She joined us from the studios of Marketplace Productions in Los Angeles.
Weeds"" airs on Monday nights on Showtime.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
In Thailand today, anti-government protesters stormed the venue of an Asian summit meeting at a beach resort south of Bangkok.
(Soundbite of protest)
They forced the Thai government to cancel the summit and evacuate some of the world leaders who had assembled there by helicopter.
The protesters are calling for the resignation of Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva, who came to power just four months(ph) ago.
The prime minister had declared a state of emergency in and around the city of Pattaya.
Joined now by NPR's Southeast Asia correspondent Michael Sullivan in Bangkok.
Michael, thanks for being with us.
Hi, Scott.
And a huge embarrassment for a country which just hasn't seemed to be able to buy political stability for a few months.
Yeah, a huge embarrassment, and they've been planning this thing for months and they decided to move it from Bangkok to prevent something like this from happening.
They mobilized thousands of security personnel to hedge their bet, but in the end none of it worked.
And we had this extraordinary sight today of hundreds, maybe thousands, of these red-shirted demonstrators streaming through the conference center unhindered.
And I have to say, the Oxford-educated Abhisit, who's normally very smooth, looked a bit rattled.
He looked a bit shaken afterwards, when he went on Thai TV to announce a state of emergency in Pattaya and the cancellation of the summit.
Not a good day, Scott, for the prime minister, and not a good day for Thailand on the world stage.
What do the protesters want?
Why, for example, do they wear red shirts?
What does that signify?
It signifies their support for the deposed prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra.
He was removed by the Thai military in 2006.
The protesters want the current prime minister, Abhisit, gone.
They want him to step down, they want new elections to be held.
They claim he came to power illegitimately after a government made up of the former prime minister's allies was forced from power in December.
So these are not the same people representing the same interests whose protests closed the airports last year?
No, no. The people who closed the airport represent the other extreme in Thailand - deeply polarized political scene.
They were supporters, or members of the so-called People's Alliance for Democracy.

I don't know if you remember, but they occupied the prime minister's office for a couple of months last year, then went after the airports in a successful effort to force what was then a Thaksin-friendly government from office with the connivance, Thaksin supporters claim, of the military and the courts.
And where is the former prime minister, Thaksin, and can you give us any feeling for his involvement or lack thereof?
He's in exile.
He was convicted last year on corruption charges.
He was sentenced to two years in prison, but he's clearly orchestrating things by remote control here.
And he remains hugely popular among Thailand's rural and urban poor, who make up the majority here, Scott.
And that's because they say he delivered for them while in office.
And as much as they love him, that's how much the other side hates him; the PAD, the middle and upper classes, the traditional political elite, the military, the monarchists.
But Thaksin, he's kept his hand in.
He appeared via videophone this week at some of the opposition rallies.
He's kept the pot stirring and today I think it was soup.
Michael, being based there in Thailand, give us your best feeling for what you see over the horizon in the next few weeks.
I think it's impossible to tell.
I mean, Prime Minister Abhisit's government took a hit today.
They badly miscalculated the level of support for Thaksin, who just won't go away.
But whether the prime minister will be forced to step down, we don't know.
But we do know that this just isn't good for Thailand's image or its economy.
I mean, the airport closures gutted the tourism industry back in December at the beginning of the high season.
And tourism officials are already saying this is going to be just as bad.
I don't think anybody knows where this is going next.
NPR's Michael Sullivan from Bangkok.
Thanks very much.
You're welcome, Scott.
Astronomers are offering the general public a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity - the chance to discover a new planet in our solar system.
NPR's science correspondent Joe Palca has the lowdown on this big idea.
The villagers are gathering under some trees for one of their community meetings.
Suddenly everyone's cell phone starts tinkling.
The actor who played the shining football star-turned singing coach on the Fox TV hit ""Glee"" has died.
Cory Monteith was found in a hotel room in Vancouver, British Columbia, on Saturday.
An autopsy is scheduled for later today, but authorities have already said that the Canadian's death doesn't appear to involve foul play.
NPR's Nathan Rott has this remembrance.
The Cory Monteith that most Americans knew wasn't Cory Monteith at all.
It was Finn Hudson, the high school football star turned glee club singer whose singing talents were discovered in the shower during the musical comedy's pilot episode.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""GLEE"")
(As Finn) (Singing) I'm getting closer than I ever thought I might...
But outside of a love for drumming, Monteith said that Finn Hudson wasn't him.
Here he is on the Canadian talk show ""George Stroumboulopolous Tonight.
